origination.corpname: Friends of the Jordan River Watershed.

did.unittitle: Friends of the Jordan River Watershed records 1967-2012, 1990-2008
did.abstract: The Friends of the Jordan River Watershed. Records contains the organizational and non-organizational records of conservation activities pertaining to the Jordan River and other fresh water bodies in the northwest corner of Michigan's Lower Peninsula.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was received from the Friends of the Jordan River Watershed, Inc. (Donor no. 10846) in November 2012.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Friends of the Jordan River Watershed records , Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: In December of 1990, thirty-three citizens in Michigan incorporated the Friends of the Jordan River Watershed (FOJ) as a non-profit organization with the stated mission to conserve the natural resources and protect the environmental quality of the Jordan River and its watershed, a land area covering roughly 125 square miles in Antrim, Charlevoix, and Otsego counties. FOJ has its beginnings in "Save the Jordan" steering committee established in 1957 to organize study of the Jordan River, its tributaries and the watershed. Organized efforts to maintain the natural resources of the Jordan River began as early as 1968 with a public campaign in Charlevoix County to "Save the Jordan." An early success of the campaign was the State of Michigan's designation of the Jordan River as "wild and scenic" under the state's Natural Rivers Act of 1970, the state's first river to achieve such a designation.

Because of the concern about development and energy extraction, researchers undertook measures to survey the watershed and its encompassing wildlife. These efforts led to several key reports and studies that guided the FOJ in its beginning stages of organization and incorporation. Over its two decades of existence, the organization has partnered with many local municipalities in the northwest corner of the Lower Peninsula of Michigan on projects or initiatives affecting water quality and the ecosystem.

In recent years, FOJ has focused its attention on a number of different issues, including legislative and executive efforts to combat the effects of hydraulic fracturing ("fracking") in the watershed area and educational outreach to K-12 schoolchildren in East Jordan. Responding to a lawsuit filed by two local municipalities (Antrim County and Star Township) and FOJ, in August of 2009 a judge in Michigan's 13th Circuit Court (Antrim County) issued an indefinite block against an energy company that sought to drill a deep-injection disposal well near the community of Alba, Michigan. The Alba well victory aligns with many of the other advocacy initiatives FOJ has pursued in its nearly twenty-five year history.

scopecontent.p: The Friends of the Jordan River Watershed. Records makes a significant contribution to understanding late twentieth and early twenty-first century environmental advocacy within the state of Michigan, especially in the Lower Peninsula's northwest corner as it relates to conservation of freshwater systems. Further, FOJ's engagement with state and local government agencies illuminates the ways in which it has been able to increase the political and regulatory salience of environmental protection, despite and amidst the simultaneous rising influence of energy companies. The records will be useful for any researcher seeking to explore these dynamics and many others related to environmental justice.

The Friends of the Jordan River Watershed. Records provides evidence of the organization's efforts to maintain the environmental and water quality of the Jordan River and its supporting water system. The collection is arranged into two series: Internal Business and External Business.

did.unittitle: Internal Business

scopecontent.p: The Internal Business series is divided into four subseries: Administration, Initiatives, Surveys and Studies, and Publications. Each of the subseries follows an alphabetical arrangement. The Administration subseries documents mainly the operations of the FOJ Board of Directors and Executive Officers and covers the years 1968 to 2006, including board meeting minutes, agendas, and annual meeting minutes. The Initiatives subseries contains the bulk of the collection that reflect the activities of the organization, including its participation in the Alba Well injection case, application for state land reserve status, and involvement in mineral exchange propositions. Scientific investigations pertaining to the Jordan River, its watershed, and nearby waterways can be found in the Surveys and Studies subseries, spanning the years 1968 to 2008. Lastly, early organizational newsletters, educational brochures, and an assortment of clippings are located in the Publications subseries.

External Business

scopecontent.p: The External Business series is divided into four subseries: Allied Organizations, Municipalities, Subject Files, and Publications. Each of the subseries follows an alphabetical arrangement. FOJ remains informed on the activities of similar environmental organizations throughout the state, region, and country. These activities are well documented in the Allied Organizations subseries. Represented are newsletters, bulletins, and annual reports of groups located primarily in northern Michigan, but also materials from other parts of the state. The Municipalities subseries is a selection of local statutes, ordinances, and plans impacting the work of FOJ in the area. The municipalities most represented are Antrim County and the City of East Jordan. The Subject Files range from 1996 to 2012 and address one of the most pressing concerns of FOJ, hydraulic fracturing ("fracking"). The Publications subseries is comprised of newspaper articles, maps, and other published materials relating to issues of interest to FOJ or other environmental organizations.
